revisions.rev:
{{lead too short|date=August 2011}} '''[[Warez group]]s''' typically tag their releases with [[.nfo|NFO]] files. Due to the nature of the [[Warez]] scene, not much is known about these groups. Listed here are many of the more significant warez groups, with a short introduction of when they were formed and what they have done. Note that there are many other warez groups that are not included here. <!-- maybe some more notable groups: Centropy, Cartel, TFE, VCDEurope, TMMVCD, TCR/TCS, VideoCD, even TEG (during somegirls time), or certain TUN pres. http://www.scenenotice.org/details.php?id=249 -->
== Apocalypse Production Crew == {{main|Apocalypse Production Crew}} Apocalypse Production Crew (styled as ''aPOCALYPSE pRODUCTION cREW'' or ''aPC'') was a major [[MP3]] [[warez]] organization founded by two individuals known under the [[pseudonym]]s ''acid^rain'' and ''Viper'' in May 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mp3scene.info/groups/view/apc/ |title=Apocalypse Production Crew on MP3Scene |publisher=MP3Scene |accessdate=2011-08-09}}</ref>
==Australian Crackers United== Australian Crackers United were primarily based in Melbourne, Australia. They existed between 1987 and 1992 largely importing warez from overseas via standard dialup modem. They focused on C games and applications.<ref>[http://kestra.exotica.org.uk/demos.php?where=group&query=Australian%20Crackers%20United BitWorld - Amiga<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==aXXo== {{main|aXXo}} aXXo is also one of the most famous{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Movie torrent groups which releases decent quality (Although not in [[High Definition Video|High-Definition]] to minimize file size) DVD rips which are very popular{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} among torrent users.
aXXo isn't a group, it was one person only, ripping movies all day.
==The Band== The Band was formed in 1987 in Belgium by Duncan, Sir 004 & Gonthar (former members of WOW on the C64), and was one of Belgium's earliest and most famous cracking groups on the [[Amiga]]. They released a lot of well known Amiga games and were one of the first to crack a new protection method, first used on the boxing game Ring Side. The group was disbanded end of 1989. Several members joined German group Vision Factory.
==Bentley Sidwell Productions== Bentley Sidwell Productions is said to have made some of the earlier IBM PC [[Crack intro|cracktro]]s, because they credited themselves with [[Color Graphics Adapter|CGA]] [[computer animation|animation]]s in their cracks.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/bentley-sidwell-productions Bentley Sidwell Productions' history]</ref> Lord Blix, the actual cracker, also wrote Gunbelt, a program for hacking long distance access codes.
==Canadian Pirates Inc== Canadian Pirates Inc were a Canadian based cracking group with BBS boards in Toronto, Ontario started in 1983 releasing Apple products.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/canadian-pirates-inc The group history]</ref>
==The Cartel== The Cartel (also known as ''ThC'') was a courier group that gave rise to The Speed Racer (TSR) as head of [[Razor 1911]] in the early 1990s.
==Centropy== {{main|Centropy}} Centropy, founded in January 1999, was a warez group which specialized in the [[Copyright infringement of software|piracy]] of films. Touting many "[[Zero day attack|0-day]]" and "negative day" releases, Centropy has notoriously released and pre-released numerous films. Among the most well known is their release of [[The Matrix Reloaded]], before it was released to [[movie theater]]s in 2003.<ref>[http://news.com.com/2100-1026_3-1001562.html?part=msnbc-cnet 'Matrix' sequel spotted on the Net CNET News.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==cRACKERS iN aCTiON== cRACKERS iN aCTiON (also known as ''CiA'')<ref name="netmag">[http://liveweb.archive.org/http://mikrom.cz/soubory/dokumenty/warez-essay.pdf Netmag: Warez je sport (Czech)]</ref>, founded in 2000 by tKC<ref name="tkc"></ref>, using IRC to communicate<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=0TxDiektLJQC&pg=PA69&dq=%22crackers+in+action%22&hl=en&ei=JNcKTsi9Ccqx8gPZwuSTAQ KybernetickÃ¡ kriminalita By VÃ¡clav JirovskÃ½]</ref><ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20001018130136/http://www.crackersinaction.com/]</ref>
==CLASS== {{main|CLASS (warez)}} CLASS (also known as ''CLS'') was a prolific game warez group which has been the repeated target of federal raids such as [[Operation Fastlink]]. They are a global group and have many members worldwide, often releasing "rip" games. The group ceased operations in 2004 after their 1,234'th release.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/class Defacto2 - Class (CLS) Group Page]</ref>
==DEViANCE== Subject to raid in [[Operation Fastlink]]. Many members are now supposedly releasing under the group name ''HATRED''.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/hatred Defacto2 - Hatred (HTD) Group Page]</ref>
==DEViSO== DEviSO was the very first video CD release group, founded in approximately 1997-1998, and went on to release some quality applications before morphing into other group incarnations.<ref>[http://theisonews.com/release.php?releaseid=1724]</ref>
==DrinkOrDie== {{main|DrinkOrDie}} DrinkOrDie (also known as ''DoD'') released a pirated copy of Windows 95 before it was released at retail stores. They were subject to a raid in [[Operation Buccaneer]].<ref>[[DrinkOrDie]]</ref>
==Echelon== {{main|Echelon (warez)}} Echelon is a warez group which specializes in the release and distribution of [[video game console|console]] games, such as [[Dreamcast]] [[ISO image|ISO]]s.<ref>[http://nfohump.com/index.php?menu=sections&sectionid=7&offset=50 Dreamcast NFOs] at nfohump.com</ref>
==The Elite Council== TEC <ref>[http://noname.c64.org/csdb/group/?id=3714]</ref> was formed in late 1987 as a full function [[Commodore 64]] importer, cracker, distributor, and demo maker with connections to TRIAD, among other groups. They released only a handful of titles before the members moved on to bigger and better groups.
==EViL== The iSO division (EViLiSO) was one of the first groups to release movies, eventually leading to many [[Topsite (warez)|topsites]] accepting VCD releases.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Released [[American Pie (film)|American Pie]] on the Internet 3 months before its theatrical release.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.theisonews.com/release.php?releaseid=4262 |title = Video CD: American Pie |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20050211094807/http://www.theisonews.com/release.php?releaseid=4262 |archivedate = 2005-02-11 |publisher = [[The iSONEWS]] }}</ref> Also released the first screener version of Star Wars episode 1.
==Fairlight== {{main|Fairlight (group)}} Fairlight (also known as ''FLT''), One of the oldest groups in warez scene, founded in 1987. While still active, the group focuses on demos.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/fairlight Defacto2 - Fairlight (FLT) Group Page]</ref> Fairlight was subject to raid in [[Operation Fastlink]], which almost killed their ISO division. Their [[Demoscene]] division was not affected by the raid.<ref>[http://www.nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=65311 Group NFO after the bust.]</ref> FLT's Iso Division is still active in 2008 and is releasing from time to time new Game Titles.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}
==FiGHTCLUB== Fightclub is new group composed of old members from HOODLUM. They released two big pc games in 2011(ARMA SE and Batman: Arkham City){{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}
==FiRM== The FiRM was a notable PC cracking group from 1989 to the early 1990s. They mainly released cracked games but also created several utilities such as [[PkUnlite]] which unpacked executables which were compressed using Phil Katz PkLite.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/the-firm The group history]</ref>
==Hoodlum== [[Hoodlum]]{{Disambiguation needed|date=July 2011}} mainly focused on cracking [[Safedisc]] and [[Securom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=search&search=true&group=HOODLUM|title=HOODLUM releases on nfohump.com}}<!--Check the nfo files--></ref> They were targeted as part of the [[Operation Site Down]] raids in 2005.<ref>http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2005/June/05_crm_353.htm</ref><ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/hoodlum Group history]</ref>
==The Humble Guys== {{main|The Humble Guys}} The Humble Guys (also known as ''THG'') were the first warez group to make use of [[.nfo|NFO files]] to document their releases.<ref>[[The Humble Guys]]</ref>
==International Network of Crackers== {{main|International Network of Crackers}} International Network of Crackers (also known as ''INC'') was one of the premier cracking/releasing warez groups for the IBM PC during the late 1980s and early 1990s. The majority of their releases during 1993 were educational games for children. By early 1994, INC had completely disappeared from the warez scene.<ref>[[International Network of Crackers]]</ref>
==Kalisto== {{main|Kalisto}} Kalisto is a [[video game console|console]] warez group established in March 1998<ref name="5year">{{cite web |url=http://nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=25965 |title=Xenosaga_Episode_One_5th_Year_Anniversary_Release_USA_PS2DVD-KALISTO |accessdate=2009-12-30 |date=2003-02-27 |publisher=NFOHump |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070312200528/http://www.nforce.nl/index.php?menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=25965 |archivedate=2007-03-12}} [http://www.ludibria.com/nfo.php?sys=ps2&sysid=973]</ref> which specializes in the release and distribution of [[PlayStation]] and [[PlayStation 2]] [[ISO image]]s, briefly moonlighting on the [[Dreamcast]] platform in mid to late 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfohump.com/index.php?menu=quicknav&item=search&search=true&group=KALISTO |title=NFOHump: Kalisto releases |accessdate=2010-02-02 |publisher=NFOHump}}</ref>
==Maven== maVen is a pirate movie release group that was active from July 25, 2004 till 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vcdq.com/index.php?grp=1193 |title=VCDQuality.com list of maVen releases |accessdate=2010-03-17}}</ref> The group was known for releasing high quality [[telesync]] versions of major blockbuster titles. In the summer of 2006, the stream of maVen releases suddenly halted. The FBI had caught GÃ©rÃ©mi Adam, one of the key members. The 27 year-old Montreal resident has been sentenced to two and a half months in prison and was also ordered to complete 100 hours of community service. He pleaded guilty to distributing two major motion pictures: [[Invincible (2006 film)|Invincible]] and [[How to Eat Fried Worms (film)|How to Eat Fried Worms]]<ref> {{cite web |url=http://torrentfreak.com/canadian-movie-piracy-maven-sent-to-jail-100317/ |title=Canadian Movie Pirate 'maVen' Sent To Jail |date=2010-03-17 |author=Ernesto |publisher=[[TorrentFreak]]}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2010/03/16/film-pirating-sentencing.html |title=Movie pirate gets 2Â½ months in jail |date=2010-03-16 |publisher=[[CBC News]]}} </ref> After the bust, releases ceased and another group called ''maVenssupplieR'' immediately took up the slack.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://torrentfreak.com/police-charge-maven-world-leader-movie-piracy-071205/ |title=Police Charge 'maVen', 'World Leader' in Internet Movie Piracy |date=2007-12-05 |author=enigmax |publisher=[[TorrentFreak]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vcdq.com/index.php?grp=1727 |title=VCDQuality.com list of maVenssupplieR releases |accessdate=2010-03-17}} </ref> In April 2010, the 28 year old GÃ©rÃ©mi Adam died of a drug overdose at the [[Pointe-aux-Trembles]] home he shared with his girlfriend, Cynthia Laporte.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://torrentfreak.com/canadian-movie-pirate-âmavenâ-dies-of-drug-overdose-100406/ |title=Canadian Movie Pirate âmaVenâ Dies of Drug Overdose |date=2010-04-06 |author=enigmax |publisher=[[TorrentFreak]]}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.24hmontreal.canoe.ca/24hmontreal/actualites/archives/2010/04/20100405-160647.html |title=Le pirate de films GÃ©rÃ©mi Adam retrouvÃ© mort Ã MontrÃ©al |date=2010-04-06 |author=Jean Nicolas AubÃ© |publisher=[[24H (newspaper)|24H MontrÃ©al]] |language=French |trans_title=Movie pirate GÃ©rÃ©mi Adam found dead in Montreal}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Montreal+film+bootlegger+dies+suspected+drug+overdose/2769334/story.html |title=Montreal film bootlegger dies of suspected drug overdose |date=2010-04-06 |author=Katherine Wilton |publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]}}</ref>
==MiRaGe== MiRaGe (also known as ''MrG'') was a prominent encoder group in the late 1990s, which operated through its [[IRC]] channel #movie-central on the [[DALnet]] network. The group received 0-day [[VCD]] releases via couriers and compressed them into the [[Advanced Systems Format|ASF]] video format, which was more suitable for mass distribution in a time where most users had [[56k]] [[dial-up]] connections. It also operated a subgroup, MrG-MV, which applied the same distribution mechanism to [[music videos]].
==Motiv8== Motiv8 (also known as ''M8'') was born in early 1991 in the [[Commodore 64]] Scene as a Demo/Release group. In 1994, led by Mason and Xerox, it split off to create the Motiv8 PC Section. In February 1998 Mason disbands the group. June 29, 1998 Motiv8 was reborn under the leadership consisting of Dogan and Highlandr. As of 2005, Motiv8 is currently still active.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/wayback/motiv8-from-1998-august-16/history/index.html The group history]</ref><ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/wayback/motiv8-from-1998-august-16/members/activem8.html member list]</ref>
==Myth== {{main|Myth (warez)}} Myth was a warez group, focused on cracking and ripping PC games. Besides ripped games, the group also released trainers and cracked updates for games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=search&search=true&group=MYTH|title=MYTH releases on nfohump.com}}</ref>
==National Elite Underground Alliance== National Elite Underground Alliance (also known as ''NEUA'') was an IBM PC warez release organization largely based out of New York which operated during the early 1990s.
==PARADOX== {{main|PARADOX (warez)}} PARADOX (also known as ''PDX'') was founded in 1989, mainly cracking/release games for the [[Amiga]]. They have since spread to the PC and other consoles. They were one of the earliest groups to successfully crack [[Windows Vista]] which was supposed to be a challenge for the hackers at the time of its release. They are one of the major warez groups still around today.
==pHAZE== The true top curry group in the scene, they were one of the most long lasting curry groups around, starting in the early 1990's and lasting until at least 2005 they were a constant #1 when it came to racing releases on the highest rated topsites in the Scene.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
==Phrozen Crew== [[File:Phrozen crew.jpg|thumb|300px|right|"The Phrozen Crew: one of the larger and more prolific Crackz groups" - PC World Magazine 1999<ref name="pcworld">Mendham, Scott. "Alt.net: Cracking Up" '''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]''' (December 1999)</ref>]]
Phrozen Crew (PC), founded in 1993 by tKC<ref name="tkc">[http://www.defacto2.net/wayback/the-life-and-legend-of-tkc-2000-october-10/index.html tKC history]</ref>{{Dead link|date=September 2011}}, was one of the most popular groups of [[computer software]] [[Software cracking|crackers]], with the tagline "We always get what we want!".<ref name="pcquest">[http://web.archive.org/web/19990508195129/http://www.pcquest.com/mar99/cracking.asp The Dark Art of Cracking] by Vinod Unny, [[PCQuest (magazine)]], March 1999.</ref>
==Pirates With Attitude== {{main|Pirates With Attitude}} Pirates With Attitude (also known as ''PWA'') were a major international warez release group from 1992 until 2000. The group was formed by two former INC members known by the pseudonyms Orion and Bar Manager. PWA made global headlines by releasing Microsoft [[Windows 98]] four weeks before it hit store shelves. PWA members were raided close after the passing of the [[NET Act|No Electronic Theft]] or "NET" Act.<ref>[http://www.usdoj.gov/criminal/cybercrime/pwa_verdict.htm Software Pirate Guilty of Copyright Infringement Under NET Act (May 15, 2001)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Project X== Project X is a scene release group that exclusively released games for the Xbox. The group was active from May 2002 until November 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://orlydb.com/?q=projectx |title=OrlyDB.com search result}} Site name is based on the [[O RLY?]] Internet phenomenon.</ref> In 2004, Project X was named as one of six groups targeted as part of [[Operation Fastlink]] by the [[United States Department of Justice]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/criminal/cybercrime/fastlink.htm |title=Justice Department Announces International Internet Piracy Sweep |accessdate=2010-02-02 |date=2004-04-22 |publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]] |location=[[Washington, D.C.]]}}</ref>
==Rabid Neurosis== {{main|Rabid Neurosis}} Rabid Neurosis (''RNS'') was an [[MP3]] warez release organization which was founded on June 6th 1996<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mp3scene.info/files/view/affinity-5-interview-with-n0fx-and-bonethug-rns/ |title=Interview with BonethuG & N0fX |date=1996-09-27 |accessdate=2011-04-05 |quote=Interviewed: N0Fx, BonethuG, Position: RNS Prez/Co-Prez. "Rabid Neurosis was founded on June 6, 1996 to be exact"}}</ref>.
==Radium== Radium (also known as ''RDM'') is known primarily for cracking and releasing high dollar audio editing software such as [[Cubase|Cubase VST]] and [[Pro Tools]]. One of their greater accomplishments was to actually speed up the [[Fraunhofer IIS|Fraunhofer]] [[MP3]] codec as well as cracking the copy protection. {{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Radium were said to have offered better support for their releases than the companies who actually manufactured the programs.<ref>[http://www.davidmccandless.com/articles/warez_wars.htm Warez Wars - Articles - David McCandless - Writer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Several verses of the rap song [http://www.zearle.com/assets/music/tracks/zearle_class_war_RETAIL/07_zearle_hackers_and_crackers_class_war.mp3 Hackers and the Crackers]" by [[Zearle]] are devoted to the group Radium. In 2004, it was discovered that some of the sounds included with the Microsoft [[Windows XP]] operating system, such as <tt>WMPAUD1.WAV</tt>, were authored using a pirated version of Sound Forge which was supplied by Radium.<ref>[http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/11/13/wmp_sound_warez_claim/ Windows Media Player sound files 'edited with warez' | Reg Developer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.kuro5hin.org/story/2004/11/15/124827/52 Microsoft Caught Out || kuro5hin.org<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Razor 1911== {{main|Razor 1911}} Razor 1911 (also known as ''RZR'') was founded in 1985 on the [[Commodore 64]] but also had a major presence on the [[Amiga]] and the [[IBM PC]]. They were subject to raid in [[Operation Buccaneer]] and [[Operation Fastlink]].
==RELOADED== {{main|RELOADED}} RELOADED (also known as ''RLD'') was founded in June 2004 from the ex-members of DEViANCE.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/reloaded History of RELOADED]</ref> They released and cracked [[Spore (2008 video game)|Spore]] 4 days <ref>{{cite web |url=http://gameviper.com/pc/spore-cracked-by-reloaded-group |title=Spore cracked before its street date |date=2008-11-03 |author=Daniel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=127807 |title=Spore-RELOADED |date=2008-09-02 |publisher=NFOHump}} </ref> and a [[The Sims 3]] [[beta version]] 15 days before their respective street dates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=140013 |title=The.Sims.3-RELOADED |date=2009-05-18 |publisher=NFOHump}} </ref> On [[February 29]], 2008, RELOADED released a cracked version of [[Assassin's Creed]], a month before it was to hit the shelves on [[March 28]]. Although, this release was later [[Nuke (warez)|nuked]] for not being the final retail version as well as having crashing issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=122515 |title=Assassins.Creed-RELOADED |date=2008-02-29 |publisher=NFOHump}}<!-- not.retail_corrupted.data.causing.crashes.and.nonworking.levels_missing.files --> </ref> The retail version was released by them more than a month later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nfohump.com/index.php?switchto=nfos&menu=quicknav&item=viewnfo&id=123249 |title=Assassins.Creed.REPACK-RELOADED |date=2008-04-08 |publisher=NFOHump}} </ref> They also released Battlefield 3, 4 days before the official release date. As well, released Modern Warfare 3 on the day that the game was released.
==Risciso== {{main|Risciso}}
Risciso (stylized as ''RISCISO'') was an online warez group, founded in approximately 1993, dedicated to distributing newly-released copyrighted software, games and movies.
==RiSE== FXP Scene Group focuses on warezing applications developed by members of The Business Software Alliance.<ref>[http://www.theisonews.com/release.php?releaseid=95194]</ref>
==RTS== Request To Send (also known as ''RTS'') is one of the oldest still existing courier groups. The group began in 1994 and is still currently active as of June 17, 2008. On September 21st, 1994, RTS beats RiSC on #warez with Wing Commander Armada. The significance of this event was massive attention drawn to RTS. That fall was rough, though, with many narc attempts on people in the scene. Many of the top boards were forced to go down during this period.
==RiSC== Rise in Superior Couriering (also known as ''RiSC'') was one of the largest courier groups during BBS era.
==SHOCK== SHOCK was founded in July 1996 from the defunct group CiA by someone going by the [[Pseudonym|alias]] Outbreak. In October 1996, SHOCK successfully merged with The Corporation (CORP). In 1998, SHOCK surpassed 1000 releases and founded an ISO division: ''SHOCKiSO''. By 1999, SHOCK had 1500 releases and 2000 releases by May 30, 2000.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/wayback/shock-circa-2000/index.html The group history]</ref><ref>http://www.defacto2.net/waybackweb/SCENELINK-from-1998-june-25/</ref>
==SKiDROW== SKiDROW is a cracking group known for breaking the UbiSoft DRM protection.<ref>http://www.infoaddict.com/skid-row-hackers-defeat-ubisoft-drm-100</ref> SKiDROW has released their content since 1990, having originated on the Amiga out of the ashes of Paranoimia. Skid Row continued for two years on Amiga before internal conflicts led to them disbanding, with members like Blackhawk returning back to resurrect Paradox. Between 2004 and 2007 they seemed to have faded away, but since 2007 they have released many things: trainers, games and cracks. Although they were releasing many games, they truly became well known in the gaming community after cracking Ubisoft's first DRM version. Silent Hunter 5: Battle of the Atlantic and Assassin's Creed II utilize this type of protection, and both have been cracked by SKiDROW, among many other games. Ubisoft's second DRM version has also been cracked by them, in games such as From Dust and Shaun White Skateboarding. Their most recent release is Assassin's Creed: Revelations for PC that was released 9 days before the official date.<ref>http://n4g.com/news/893016/assassins-creed-revelations-pc-leaked-a-week-before-official-release</ref>
==Superior Art Creations== {{main|Superior Art Creations}} Superior Art Creations (''SAC'') is an underground [[computer art scene|artscene]] group which caters primarily to and is well known within the warez|warez scene.
==TECHNiC== TECHNiC is a small group from France, mostly active around 2004. They specialized on ripping games but they reportedly released stolen cracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defacto2.net/file/detail/a32d35 |title= Standard Rip Rules (S.R.R) |date=2004-03-05}}</ref> The group was known for releasing rip versions of games which would not be released by the more 'accepted' groups due to size limitation rules introduced in the S.R.R.
==Tristar and Red Sector Incorporated== {{main|Tristar and Red Sector Incorporated}} Tristar and Red Sector, Inc. (also known as ''TRSI'') began as an alliance between two warez groups: Tristar and [[Red Sector Incorporated]]. They were formed in 1990 as a cooperative [[Commodore 64]] demo coding and cracking group. TRSI migrated from the Commodore 64 release platform to the Amiga and IBM-PC, and eventually branched off into the console gaming scene before finally disbanding their warez division.<ref>[[Tristar and Red Sector Incorporated]]</ref> In late 2003, TRSI became inactive and remains so today.<ref>[http://www.trsi.org TRSI's website]</ref>
==United Software Association== {{main|United Software Association}} The United Software Association (also known as ''USA'') was a prominent IBM PC games and applications warez group during the 1990s. USA formed an alliance with the PC warez division of Fairlight which was known as "USA/FLT". In late January of 1992, several members of USA were arrested by the [[United States Secret Service]] and the [[Farmington Hills, Michigan]] police for credit card fraud.<ref>[[United Software Association]]</ref>
==We Love Warez== We Love Warez (also known as ''WLW'') was subject to raid during [[Operation Buccaneer]], [[Operation Fastlink]], and [[Operation Safehaven]].<ref>[http://www.cybercrime.gov/singhPlea.htm Ohio Man Pleads Guilty to Copyright Infringement.]</ref>
==Syntonic Crackers== Syntonic Crackers was started in 1997 by uNDeRWoRLD and CyBorg in a Dutch regional town. After a major diskcrash, thousands of patches and keygens collected between 1991-1996 by TUWBBS (a 046-region based Bulletin Board System) got lost. The BBS sysop (Underworld) and co-sysop (Cyborg) decided to switch from DOS to the much disliked Win95. This event marked the end of TUWBBS, the Dutch HQ for groups TPiNC (Dutch-based Techno Products, Inc.), MCC (Belgian Mack Crack Corp.), pHROZEN cREW, and UCF (German-based United Cracking Force). Both sysops cracked DOS software for several years producing only Cracks&Patches and went on the Win95 challenge for a summer project: Syntonic Crackers. During one summer holidays, Syntonic released over 150 keygens for Windows software, proving that Win95 software was fairly easy to reverse-engineer compared to MS-DOS products. Their aim was to deliver only few-KB sized releases that would technically compete releases of other groups like pHROZEN cREW who were very productive and often cracked the same software. The group stopped it's activities a year later.
==Techno Products, Inc.== TPiNC was a Dutch cracking group in the pre-internet era mainly cracking DOS-software, BBS-software, and producing crypters and decrypters for executable files. The group consisted of 4-5 members all based in The Netherlands. They organised one of the first cracking parties in The Netherlands before the rise of the internet. The first TPiNC party, publicly held in Tilburg, was attended by a international crew of crackers and virus-writers from Poland, Belgium and Germany (United Cracking Force).
